problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. What is the remainder when $2^{87} +3$ is divided by $7$?
solution: We are looking at powers of 2, so we notice that $2^3=8=7+1$.  Therefore  \[2^3\equiv1\pmod7.\] In particular \[2^{87}\equiv2^{3\cdot29}\equiv 8^{29}\equiv 1^{29}\equiv1\pmod7.\] Therefore \[2^{87}+3\equiv1+3\equiv4\pmod7.\] The remainder upon division by 7 is $\boxed{4}$.

We see a pattern where the remainders repeat every $3$ powers of $2$. So $2^{87} \equiv 2^{3*29} \equiv (2^3)^{29} \equiv 1^{29} \equiv 1 \mod 7$.

Now, adding $3$ to this gives a remainder of $4$ when divided by $7$. So, the remainder when $2^{87} +3$ is divided by $7$ is $4$.
